note.p: “To day we pass the Alps” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—The Ruskin family approached the Alps for the first time from the north, traveling from Schaffhausen and Constance, and they crossed into Italy through the Via Mala and the Splügen Pass (see Tour of 1833).

To describe the approach and crossing, Ruskin apparently intended, according to his Plan for Continuation of the Account of a Tour on the Continent, to situate the present poem in a section named “Passing the Alps”. This section title is followed by others related to the Alpine crossing, for most of which Ruskin drafted at least a verse componeent:

list.item: “Passing the Alps”, for which the poem “Passing the Alps” is extant;
“Via Mala”, for which the poem “Via Mala” is extant;
“Splugen”, for which the poem “Splugen” is extant;
“The Summit”, for which the poem “The Summit” is extant;
“The Descent”, for which the poem “The Descent” is extant;
“Italia, Italia”, for which no readily identifiable composition survives.

note.p: Also according to the List of Proposed Additional Contents for the Account, Ruskin meant to lead up to this group with another group relating to the first distant sightings of the Alps and of Swiss character in the borderland between Germany and Switzerland. This group was to be positioned following the last section that Ruskin succeeded in fair‐copying (incompletely) in MS IX, [Heidelberg]:

list.item: “Strasburg”, for which no readily identifiable composition survives;
“The swiss cottages”, for which no readily identifiable composition survives;
“Schaffhausen”, for which the poem “Splugen” is extant;
“The Alps”, for which the poem “The Summit” is extant;
“The Fall of the Rhine”, for which the poem “The Descent” is extant;
“Constance”, for which there survives no readily identifiable composition.
“Werdenberg”, for which there survives no readily identifiable composition.
““Pfaffers””, for which there survives no readily identifiable composition.
“Werdenberg”, for which there survives no readily identifiable composition.

note.p: Ruskin models this arrangement on Italy by Samuel Rogers (1763–1855), in which a poem about the western Alpine pass, “The Great St. Bernard”, gives way to “The Descent”, followed (after two intervening narrative poems) by “The Alps”. In the latter poem, Rogersʼs speaker retraces imaginatively the entire span of the crossing, preparing for his celebration of arrival in the following poems about Italy. (Between “The Descent” and “The Alps”, Rogers pauses to relate two verse tales: “Jorasse”, a highland tale about an intrepid Alpine hunter; and “Marguerite de Tours”, a lowland tale about a girl who crosses from Martigny, on the Swiss side of the St. Bernard, to the opposite vale of Aosta in order to attend to her dying father. In the 1839 edition, Rogers added a third tale, “The Brothers”, about twin brothers who lose their infant brother to an eagle.)

Similarly, according to both Ruskinʼs List of Proposed Additional Contents for the “Account” and the internal evidence of his poem, “Passing the Alps”, he meant the latter to serve the structural function of Rogersʼs “The Alps”, by working as a summary reflection on the experience of crossing. Both poems also use a trope of the Alps as a “barrier” between civilizations, a trope developed by a historical reference to Hannibal as the sublime analogy for struggling against that barrier. (Hannibalʼs crossing is more pertinent to Rogersʼs travelogue, which follows the same western approach, than to Ruskinʼs, but the younger poetʼs imagination may have been captured by Turnerʼs vignette for “The Alps” in the 1830 illustrated edition of Italy, which depicts the Carthaginian invaders filing through the mountains with their elephants.) Thus, Ruskin captures Rogersʼs idea of one poem serving as an epitome of the experience of crossing that is elaborated—topographically, historically, anecdotally—in surrounding poems.

As a difference between Ruskinʼs and Rogersʼs crossing poems, Ruskin, according to his proposed plan, intended to situate the poem, “Passing the Alps”, at the head of a cluster about a mountain pass, unlike Rogers who posed “The Alps” as a retrospection, following poems that carry the reader over the pass. In another difference, Ruskinʼs “Passing the Alps” develops the vision of Hannibalʼs invasion as its sole topic, whereas in “The Alps” Rogers characteristically crowds numerous historical references in order to contrast the turbulent past with his speakerʼs present “path of pleasure” (Rogers, Italy [1830], 30). Ruskin, at this age, typically focused more on topographical than historical features, for which he lacked sufficient erudition.

According to this interpretation of the derivation and function of “Passing the Alps”, W. G. Collingwood violated Ruskinʼs structural intentions. As the first editor to reconstruct the “Account” by appending draft to Ruskinʼs MS IX fair copy, Collingwood erred in placing “Passing the Alps” between “Genoa” and “Chamouni” (the latter collected from MS VII), causing Ruskinʼs poem to function as a transition between Italy and Switzerland, rather than between Germany and Italy. The latter arrangement appears to have been in Ruskinʼs mind as early as the MS IA, g.2 sequence, which pairs “Passing the Alps” with “Milan Cathedral”—even though the reference in “Passing the Alps” to Hannibalʼs crossing is more appropriately connected with the western passage.

In another view, however, Collingwoodʼs erroneous placement of “Passing the Alps” was inspired, for while he disrupted Ruskinʼs elaboration of Rogersʼs model, the editor used available materials to patch together an approximation of how Ruskinʼs cluster of poems about the north to south crossing would eventually have been mirrored by a cluster about the east to west crossing. According to Ruskinʼs proposed plan, the Splügen cluster, extending from sections entitled “Passing the Alps” through “The Descent” and poems on the Italian lakes, would have been mirrored in reverse by a cluster including “The Ascent” and “The Grand St. Bernard” leading to “The Lake of Geneva”—and had Ruskin completed these poems and essays, he would perhaps have exploited Rogersʼs tropes about crossings here as well. Collingwoodʼs solution indirectly points to another instance of Ruskinʼs having abandoned work on the “Account” because he achieved his goals, and protracting his labors would have proved redundant (see Account of a Tour on the Continent: Discussion—Sources).
“The barrier of boundless length” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Cf. “To me they [the Alps] seemed the barriers of a world” (Rogers, Italy (1830), 30).
“The Queen of nations” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Ancient Rome.

“The Carthaginian foe . . . Avalanches roar” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—In 218 BC, near the start of the Second Punic War between Carthage and Rome, the Carthaginian leader, Hannibal, led his army on an unprecedented march across the Alps, invading Italy and surprising Rome via a western passage somewhere in present‐day Piedmont.
“Cannæs plain” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—An area in Apulia, in southeast Italy, where Hannibalʼs army won a major victory over a large Roman force in 216 BC.
